text.0: glorify him whose might is allsurpassing indra the muchinvoked who fights uninjured.
text.1: magnify with these songs the nevervanquished the strong the bull of men the mighty victor.
text.2: he champion hero warrior lord of battles impetuous loudly roaring great destroyer.
text.3: who whirls the dust on high alone oerthrower hath made all races of mankind his subjects.
text.4: thou thou alone hast tamed the dasyus singly thou hast subdued the people for the Ārya.
text.5: in this or is it not thine hero exploit indra declare it at the proper season.
text.6: for true i deem thy strength is thine the mighty thine o most potent thine the conquering victor.
text.7: strong of the strong most mighty of the mighty thine driver of the churl to acts of bounty.
text.8: be this our ancient bond of friendship with you and with aṅgirases here who speak of vala.
text.9: thou wondrous shaker of things firm didst smite him in his fresh strength and force his doors and castles.
text.10: with holy thoughts must he be called the mighty showing his power in the great fight with vṛtra.
text.11: he must be called to give us seed and offspring the thunderer must he moved and sped to battle.
text.12: he in his might with name that lives for ever hath far surpassed all human generations.
text.13: he most heroic hath his home with splendour with glory and with riches and with valour.
text.14: stranger to guile who neer was false or faithless bearing a name that may be well remembered.
text.15: indra crushed cumuri dhuni Śambara pipru and Śuṣṇa that their castles fell in ruin.
text.16: with saving might that must be praised and lauded indra ascend thy car to smite down vṛtra.
text.17: in thy right hand hold fast thy bolt of thunder and weaken bounteous lord his art and magic.
text.18: as agni as the dart burns the dry forest like the dread shaft burn down the fiends o indra.
text.19: thou who with high deepreaching spear hast broken hast covered over mischief and destroyed it.
text.20: with wealth by thousand paths come hither agni paths that bring ample strength o thou most splendid.
text.21: come son of strength oer whom invoked of many the godless hath no power to keep thee distant.
text.22: from heaven from earth is bruited forth the greatness of him the firm the fiery the resplendent.
text.23: no foe hath he no counterpart no refuge is there from him the conqueror full of wisdom.
text.24: this day the deed that thou hast done is famous when thou for him with many thousand others.
text.25: laidest low kutsa Āyu atithigva and boldly didst deliver tūrvayāṇa.
text.26: in thee o god the wisest of the sages all gods were joyful when thou slewest ahi.
text.27: when lauded for thyself thou gavest freedom to soreafflicted heaven and to the people.
text.28: this power of thine both heaven and earth acknowledge the deathless gods acknowledge it o indra.
text.29: do what thou neer hast done o mighty worker beget a new hymn at thy sacrifices.
